qas.question: In what year did Pierre de Fermat declare Fermat's little theorem?
Besides Leibniz, what other mathematician proved the validity of Fermat's little theorem?
Of what form do Fermat numbers take?
To what extent did Fermat confirm the validity of Fermat numbers?
Of what form do Mersenne primes take?
In what year did Pierre de Fermat declare Euler's little theorem?
Besides Beibniz, what other mathematician proved the validity of Euler's little theorem?
Of what form do Euler numbers take?
To what extent did Fermat confirm the validity of Euler numbers?
Of what form do Euler primes take?

context: After the Greeks, little happened with the study of prime numbers until the 17th century. <a0_0><b5_0>In <a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4>1640<b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> Pierre de Fermat stated (without proof) Fermat's little theorem (later proved by Leibniz and <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><b6_0>Euler<b6_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>). Fermat also conjectured that all numbers of the form <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4><b7_0>22n + 1<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> are prime (they are called Fermat numbers) and he verified this <a3_0><a3_1><b8_0>up to <a3_3><a3_4>n = 4<a3_4/><a3_3/> (or <a3_2>216 + 1<a3_2/>)<b8_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. However, the very next Fermat number 232 + 1 is composite (one of its prime factors is 641), as Euler discovered later, and in fact no further Fermat numbers are known to be prime. The French monk Marin Mersenne looked at primes of the form <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a4_3><a4_4><b9_0>2p − 1<b9_0/><a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_0/>, with p a prime<a4_1/>. They are called Mersenne primes in his honor.
